contents.context:
A draft budget report submitted to the annual session of the National People's Congress on Friday shows China has set its 2020 defense budget at 175 billion U.S. dollars, targeting an increase of 6.6 percent from the previous year.
This exceeds analysts' expectations of a less than three percent increase.
This year's draft defense budget marks the smallest increase in recent years, but considering the economic damage caused by COVID-19, it still shows that China is willing to spend big on military development amid rising tensions between Beijing and Washington.

"(The) context is that they're stepping up their rivalry in many different respects and I think defense is also a big part of it because of the provocations in the South China Sea recently. And that kind of has implications of butting heads together."

China is also poised to tighten its control of Hong Kong by enacting new security laws aimed at quashing anti-government protests and other dissent.
Beijing sees these laws necessary to protect China from what it calls "external forces" determined to undermine its sovereignty.
The proposal raises the likelihood of more violent demonstrations like those that gripped Hong Kong last year during which the U.S. said it would respond strongly to any crackdown in Hong Kong.
A report to Congress released by the White House earlier this week shows the Trump administration is promising a "competitive approach" towards China that calls for a "fundamental reevaluation of how the U.S. understands and responds" to Chinese leadership.
The report claims Beijing challenges the "bedrock American belief in the unalienable right of every person to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness."
Kim Ji-yeon, Arirang News.
Reporter : jiyeonkim@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
China's 2020 defense budget growth target at 6.6% amid COVID-19 woes
Updated: 2020-05-22 17:22:29 KST

contents.context:
No economic growth target for China in 2020.
Beijing skipped setting a specific GDP goal for the first time ever, admitting that China was facing an unpredictable time.

"This is because the country will face some factors that are difficult to predict due to the great uncertainty regarding the COVID-19 pandemic and the world economic and trade environment."

But analysts also point out that Beijing could be keeping quiet about its growth targets to prevent the U.S. from using stronger measures against China.

"Because China is running a conflict right now between President Trump, conflict of words, China may believe that a type of positive, optimistic growth estimate may induce President Trump to become even harsher."

Most of the attendees, except Chinese leader Xi Jinping and some other high-up officials, gathered in masks on Friday for a condensed version of the annual congress after a two-month delay due to the pandemic.
To pick up its sluggish economy, for the first time in 13 years, Beijing will issue special treasury bonds worth around 140 billion U.S. dollars.
China's GDP last year grew by 6.1 percent, achieving its official target range of 6 to 6.5 percent.
But in the first quarter of this year, China's economy has already shrunk by 6.8 percent compared to Q1 last year.
And the IMF believes that it will only grow by just 1.2 percent this year.
Kim Dami, Arirang News.
Reporter : damikim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
China will not set GDP target for 2020 as COVID-19 batters global economy
Updated: 2020-05-22 17:21:40 KST

contents.context:
China's biggest annual political event of the year, the "Two Sessions" kicked off on Thursday, after a two month-long delay due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
The gathering opened with a minute's silence for the people who have died of COVID-19.
Thousands of delegates bowed their heads in silence after singing the national anthem at Beijing's Great Hall of the People.
While the event is usually held for around ten days, this year's event has been shortened, and some sessions are to be held over video link.
Reporter : jhee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
China's biggest political event starts with 1 minute silence for COVID-19 victims
Updated: 2020-05-22 10:04:56 KST

contents.context:
The Director of the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, Andrea Ammon says that, although the timing and size is unknown, a second wave of COVID-19 is expected to hit Europe at some point.
She explained 85 percent to 90 percent of Europe's population is still vulnerable to the virus, which is circulating much more than it did in January and February.
She warned that it's not the time to completely relax, and stressed Europe should ready itself for a second wave.
Italy, one of the hardest-hit countries in Europe with more than 228-thousand cases and some 32-thousand deaths, is also expressing concerns over a possible second wave.
Italy's Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte thanked citizens on Thursday for following quarantine measures and said the worst had passed.
That said, he still urged citizens to respect social distancing rules and to wear face masks, stressing that now is not the time for parties or enjoying nightlife and big gatherings.
He warned that if infection rates rise again, the country will go back on lockdown.
Elsewhere in Europe, COVID-19 cases in the UK have now topped 250-thousand and death toll has surpassed 36-thousand.
The UK government said around 17 percent of people in London and around 5 percent or more of the rest of the UK have tested positive for coronavirus antibodies, meaning they've already had the illness.
Further afield, Iran reported nearly 2,4-hundred new cases on Thursday, its highest daily rate in nearly 50 days.
This raised the country's total infections to nearly 130-thousand.
Russia, despite its relatively low death rate, has the second most confirmed cases in the world, with a total of around 317-thousand cases and more than three-thousand deaths.
Kim Jae-hee, Arirang News.
Reporter : jhee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Second wave of COVID-19 expected in Europe: ECDC
Updated: 2020-05-22 10:03:56 KST

contents.context:
IOC chief Thomas Bach says the Tokyo Games will have to be scrapped altogether IF the event cannot be held next summer.
Speaking to BBC Sport on Thursday, Bach said "you can't forever employ thousands of people in an organizing committee, and also leave the athletes in uncertainty."
Bach said all possible scenarios are under consideration and he called it a "mammoth task" and said staging such a massive sporting event behind closed doors is (quote) "not what we want."
In March, the IOC and Japanese officials made the unprecedented decision to postpone the Olympics to next year-- as coronavirus gripped the world.
Reporter : ashin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
Tokyo Olympics would have to be cancelled if not held in 2021: IOC chief
Updated: 2020-05-22 10:03:56 KST

contents.context:
The U.S. government has tightened its strict economic regulations on Chinese tech-giant Huawei as it looks to break free of China-based supply chains.
On top of that, the U.S. Under Secretary of State for Economic Growth, Energy, and the Environment, Keith Krach says the nation discussed on Thursday the Economic Prosperity Network with South Korea and other its allies, urging them to isolate the Chinese firm together.
Last year, the Trump administration included Huawei on its unreliable entity list to limit the company's business activities in the U.S.
Reporter : peterwjchoi@gmail.com
contents.headline:
U.S. urges S. Korea, other allies to stem their Huawei supply chains
Updated: 2020-05-22 10:00:10 KST

contents.context:
China will NOT set a specific economic growth target for 2020 as COVID-19 continues to batter its economy.
In the National People's Congress report on Friday, Chinese Premier Li Keqiang said China is facing an unpredictable time.
Li also pointed to the global pandemic and uncertainties in the economy and trade.
For the first time in 13 years, Beijing will issue special national bonds worth around 140 billion U.S. dollars.
Last year, China's GDP grew by 6.1 percent, achieving its official target range of 6 to 6.5 percent.
But in the first quarter of this year, China's economy shrank 6.8 percent on-year.
Reporter : damikim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
China will not set GDP target for 2020 as COVID-19 batters global economy
Updated: 2020-05-22 09:59:03 KST

contents.context:
China is proposing a controversial new security law in Hong Kong that could ban sedition, secession and subversion-- a move likely to fuel anger in the city.
Beijing proposed the legislation during its delayed annual meeting of parliament-- a move that critics say will effectively end the territory's autonomy.
Demonstrators in Hong Kong are furious at what they see as an erosion of the territory's independence by mainland China.
Shortly after Beijing's move, U.S. lawmakers proposed a bill that would essentially sanction any Chinese officials that enforce such a law.
President Trump also says the U.S. will react strongly if China follows through with its plans.

Reporter : ashin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
China proposes sweeping national security law for Hong Kong
Updated: 2020-05-22 09:57:51 KST

contents.context:
Washington and Beijing are continuing to trade verbal barbs, after U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo called China, a 'brutal, authoritarian regime' on Wednesday, in response to China's decision to target Australia with barley tariffs after a call for an independent probe into the origins of COVID-19.
At a news conference Thursday, China's Foreign Ministry slammed Pompeo's remarks.

"Once again Mr. Pompeo made irresponsible remarks, and he has played to perfection the part of an extremely irresponsible politician. But his numerous lies have bankrupted his credibility in the world."

In response to the U.S. pointing the finger at China's initial handling of the COVID-19 outbreak as the reason for the global pandemic, the spokesperson said the outbreak in the U.S. is solely on them, not China.

With regard to COVID-19, as the Secretary of State of the Unites States, Mr. Pompeo should tell the world why the U.S. government didn't take strong prevention and control measures between January and March, why it was for such a long time against people wearing masks, and why it failed to stem the fast spread of COVID-19 in the U.S.. He has a responsibility to explain to the world."

Trade tensions are also escalating between the two biggest economies, as the U.S. Senate on Wednesday passed legislation that could ban many Chinese companies from listing on U.S. stock exchanges.
The bill would require companies to certify "they are not owned or controlled by a foreign government".
While the law could be applied to any foreign company, watchers say the move to strengthen disclosure requirements is aimed squarely at Beijing.
Lee Seung-jae, Arirang News.
Reporter : seungjae86@gmail.com
contents.headline:
China responds to Pompeo's 'brutal, authoritarian' remark
Updated: 2020-05-22 09:57:51 KST

contents.context:
The U.S. will withdraw from the Open Skies Treaty, a treaty that permits unarmed surveillance flights over almost three dozen nations.
U.S. President Donald Trump says Russia didn't "adhere" to the treaty, so until Moscow changes its ways, the U.S. will pull out.
U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said the U.S. withdrawal will take effect in six months' time.
But Pompeo added the U.S. might reconsider should Russia return to full compliance.
In response, Russia's Foreign Ministry denied violating the treaty, and said the U.S. withdrawal would be "very regrettable", affecting all of the treaty's participants.
Reporter : jhee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Trump administration to withdraw U.S. from Open Skies Treaty due to Russia's non-compliance
Updated: 2020-05-22 07:20:43 KST

contents.context:
Italy, one of the countries hardest-hit by COVID-19, has expressed concerns over a possible second wave.
Italy's Prime Minister said Thursday that, while the worst has passed, if infection rates rise again, the country will go back on lockdown.
He urged citizens to respect social distancing rules and to wear face masks.
He stressed that now is not the time for parties, nightlife or big gatherings.
The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control is also warning that although its timing and size is unknown, a second wave is expected to hit Europe.
Meanwhile, COVID-19 continues to claim more victims.
The death toll now stands at more than 36-thousand in the UK.
Iran reported nearly 2,4-hundred new cases on Thursday, the highest daily cases reported in nearly 50 days.
Reporter : jhee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Italy to go back to lockdown restrictions if infection rates rise again
Updated: 2020-05-22 07:20:24 KST

contents.context:
With a barrage of sharp rhetoric and the trade war now back on again, the United States and China are drawing their battle lines, hindering the world from tackling COVID-19.
Experts say the sudden flare up of tensions started as the two sides play the blame game to justify their own slow responses to the pandemic.

"If you look at the U.S., of course it's election year and Donald Trump is doing everything he can to deflect from a less than stellar performance in dealing with the pandemic within the United States. Now if you look at the Chinese side, Xi has to carry a fair amount of blame for creating the culture that stopped local officials in Wuhan from speaking up and reporting just how bad the outbreak was when it could have been contained within China."

But at the heart of the bilateral feud is a battle for supremacy in trade, security and emerging technologies to grow their geopolitical influence.
Trump is targeting China's biggest tech companies, in a fresh round of their trade war, to curb major technological advances like 5G.

"Whoever masters the technologies of today and tomorrow will probably be the dominant power in the coming decades. And control for large part, shape of the future of the 21st century."

Meanwhile, China seems to be employing the divide and conquer strategy on America's longtime allies, supplying protective masks to the EU and donating 2 billion U.S. dollars to the World Health Organization.

"The Chinese have mastered what the West deems to be multilateral diplomacy, and they're very effective at deploying that language when, however, they are called out for behavior that doesn't match that rhetoric, they can be quite acidic."

But as long as the pandemic continues, experts say these proxy battles won't benefit either side, and will hinder global efforts to counter the virus, protect economies and develop a working vaccine.
The world's biggest economies will have to put their rivalry aside for the time being.
Oh Soo-young, Arirang News.
Reporter : osy@arirang.com
contents.headline:
U.S., China engage in proxy battles to win global supremacy: experts
Updated: 2020-05-21 17:21:03 KST
